topic: Nature of Science Inquiry in Biology, Nature of Biology (Introduction)
content: Introduction to Biology as a science.
Describing the scientific inquiry method.
Investigating the initial stages of scientific inquiry: observation, identifying a problem, forming a hypothesis.
Exploring the fundamental nature and importance of Biology.

Investigating the stages of scientific inquiry ( observation, identifying a problem, forming hypothesis );
Categorise the study of Biology by Exploring the nature of Biology;

topic: Nature of Science Inquiry in Biology (Application), Nature of Biology (Branches and Concept Map)
content: Investigating the latter stages of scientific inquiry: testing hypothesis through experimentation, recording and analysing data, forming a conclusion.
Applying the scientific inquiry method to investigate biological facts and phenomena in given situations.
Sharing the findings of investigations with peers through presentations or reports.
Using the findings of investigations to solve real-life problems.
Identifying the various branches of biology (botany, zoology, entomology, genetics, mycology).
Creating a concept map to illustrate the nature of Biology and its branches.
outcomes: Investigating the stages of scientific inquiry ( testing hypothesis through experimentation, recording and analysing data, forming a conclusion );
Applying scientific inquiry method in investigating biological facts and phenomena given a situation;
Sharing the findings of the investigations with peers;
Using the findings of the investigations to solve real life problems.
Identifying the branches of biology ( botany, zoology, entomology, genetics, mycology );
Creating a concept map on the nature of Biology.

content: Introduction to the hierarchical organisation of life.
Classifying levels of biological organisation from the simplest to the most complex: atom, molecule, cell, tissue, organ, system, organism, population, communities, ecosystem, biosphere.
outcomes: Classify the levels of biological organisation from simple to complex by Classifying levels of biological organisation ( atom, molecule, cell, tissue, organ, system, organism, population, communities, ecosystem, biosphere ).
references: Syllabus Unit Concepts and Methods in Biology

content: Investigating the characteristics of living things: feeding/nutrition, respiration, excretion, reproduction.
Observing and discussing examples for each characteristic.
Distinguishing between living things and non-living things based on observed characteristics.
outcomes: Investigating the characteristics of living things(feeding/nutrition, respiration, excretion, reproduction );
Distinguishing living things from non-living things;
references: Syllabus Unit Concepts and Methods in Biology

topic: Characteristics of Living Things (Part 2), Life Processes
content: Investigating the remaining characteristics of living things: sensitivity/irritability, movement/locomotion, growth.
Analysing the comprehensive concept of 'life' based on all characteristics.
Describing the various life processes occurring in living organisms.
Analysing the significance and mechanisms of these life processes.
Categorising life processes into catabolism and anabolism, explaining their roles in metabolism.
outcomes: Investigating the characteristics of living things(sensitivity/irritability, movement/locomotion, growth );
Analysing the concept of life.
Describing life processes in living organisms;
Analysing life processes in living organisms;
Categorising life processes of living organisms ( catabolism and anabolism ).
references: Syllabus Unit Concepts and Methods in Biology

content: Exploring different types of microscopes, including simple and compound microscopes.

Identifying and relating parts of a compound microscope to their specific functions: eyepiece lens, objective lenses, body tube, adjustment knobs (fine and coarse), revolving nose piece, stage, diaphragm, aperture, light source, arm, and base.
outcomes: Exploring different types of microscopes ( simple and compound microscopes );
Relating parts of a compound microscope to the functions(eye piece lens, objective lenses, body tube, adjustment knobs revolving nose piece, stage, diaphragm, aperture, light source, arm and base );

Calculating the total magnification of examined specimens.
Examining the basic structure of cells from different organisms using a microscope.

Calculating magnification of examined specimen.

content: Illustrating the basic structure of cells through diagrams and drawings.
Creating physical or digital models of cells to show their basic structure.
Investigating various eukaryotic cells, focusing on plant and animal cells, as well as examples like fungi and amoeba.

Differentiating between eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells based on their structural components.
Explaining the functions of key organelles found in animal and plant cells.
